awd_titl_txt: Travel Grant: Enabling Faculty at Under-Resourced Primarily Undergraduate Institutions to Attend the 2024 Fall American Geophysical Union (AGU) Annual Meeting
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will initiate a Travel Grant program for faculty from typically under-resourced institutions, such as Emerging Research Institutions (ERIs), Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs), and community colleges.  Faculty at these institutions often have higher teaching loads and do not have access to significant travel funds, making it more difficult for them to attend scientific conferences.  Attendance at conferences allows faculty to establish connections to other researchers and bring back the latest innovations in research and teaching to their classrooms.

The American Geophysical Union’s (AGU’s) Fall Meeting is a large gathering of Geoscience professionals, with >22,000 attendees from 100+ countries.  This award will initiate a Travel Grant program for up to 50 early-to-mid career faculty from under-resourced institutions to attend the 2024 Fall AGU meeting.  The application process will be similar to the current AGU student travel program and advertising for the program will be conducted across multiple avenues.  In addition to a travel stipend, the travel grant awardees will have the opportunity to participate in a professional development workshop, networking and social events, co-chair sessions at the conference, and review student presentations.  There will be pre- and post-event evaluation surveys and one or more journal articles will result from the award.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded pilot program supported the participation of 49 faculty members from primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) at the AGU 2024 Annual Meeting, the largest Earth and space science conference in the U.S. Without this support, many of these educators, including those from two-year colleges (2YCs) and smaller four-year institutions, would not have been able to attend.

The program provided financial assistance, professional development, and networking opportunities tailored to the needs of these faculty members. It strengthened the scientific community by expanding participation and connecting educators with the latest research, tools, and funding opportunities. Faculty engaged directly with leading science at AGU, attended technical workshops and policy panels, and took part in mentoring activities—enhancing both their professional growth and their ability to support students.

A virtual orientation session in October 2024 prepared the group for the December 2024 conference by covering logistics, expectations, and resources, including remarks from NSF program staff. Each participant created an introductory slide to help foster a sense of community before arriving. At AGU, participants attended at least two full days of the conference and selected learning opportunities that matched their interests, such as sessions on mentoring, communication, research planning, and science education.

A key highlight was a customized NSF information workshop developed in collaboration with NSF program directors. Many participants had not previously engaged with NSF or had limited experience with federal funding. The session included an overview of funding programs in geoscience and STEM education and guidance on proposal writing and review.  Optional activities, including a visit to NSF headquarters and individual meetings with program officers, helped deepen these connections.

Survey feedback collected after the conference showed that participants gained significant value from the experience. Responses reflected a strong sense of accomplishment (average rating 4.5 out of 5) and connection (4.3). Participants reported feeling more inspired to mentor students, apply for funding, and engage with the geoscience community. As one faculty member shared: “This grant not only made it possible financially, but also provided a great space to feel truly included and encouraged participation in a way that I had not done before.” The benefits extended beyond the individual participants. Faculty brought back new ideas to enhance their teaching such as incorporating interactive learning, scientific writing, and data-focused lab activities. Several planned to pursue research grants, share resources with colleagues, or build student internship opportunities through new professional contacts. One participant wrote: “Meeting new people will allow me to build connections that could develop into collaborative research and service projects and provide my students with potential internship, career, and mentorship opportunities.”

Participants also shared helpful feedback for future improvements, including challenges related to travel costs, the large size of the meeting, and timing during the academic term. Still, there was strong enthusiasm and appreciation for the experience. One attendee noted: “[The] institution does not support adjunct faculty for travel to AGU. The support from NSF makes one feel valued in their work with students and excites one to further this commitment.” The program made efficient use of existing AGU infrastructure, such as a travel grant application portal and conference workshops to achieve impact with modest funding. The high demand for this opportunity, nearly double the number of applicants than available spaces underscores its value. There is strong potential to grow this effort in future years by building connections to AGU Sections, expanding PUI faculty contributions to the conference,  and increasing PUI leadership within the AGU community. 

By expanding access to professional opportunities, strengthening faculty development, and fostering new connections, this program advanced both teaching and research excellence and engagement. It brought fresh voices and energy into the geoscience community and helped build a more connected and dynamic network of educators and researchers - an essential part of training the future geoscience workforce.
